events.name: Barriers to production: A tech problem or a cultural one? @Strata+HadoopWorldSG
events.description: This session is a part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: Unifying the data team and the IT department is a crucial step for developing and deploying predictive data solutions in any organization, but communication between the two is almost always an issue. Pauline Brown analyzes the cultural, technical, and historical reasons that have led to a rift between the data team and the IT department and explains how rethinking the process can change the game. Technical reasons: Data scientists and IT team members (engineers and developers) aren’t trained with the same tools or programming languages, and these languages don’t coexist or work well together. IT teams have used historical tool stacks, technologies, and languages that are almost part of their religion—things that have already proven a certain stability in the enterprise, but young data scientists are showing up with newer languages like R or Python and using open source technologies. Neither IT nor DS teams want (or have the time) to learn a new way to think and program. Thus, the very nature of their collaboration can cause issues. IT teams typically don’t want the data science team to use “technology X” because they don’t want to deal with running it into production or risk breaking a cluster and having to restart it manually. This in turn limits the effectiveness of the data science team and causes frustrations on both ends. Cultural reasons: The difference between the two types of teams stems from the nature of the expectations—data scientists are expected to explore and discover, whereas IT teams are expected to maintain stability and keep things running. If a data scientist breaks something in their analysis, the repercussions are usually relatively low impact. If an engineer breaks something in production, this could have dramatic effects (only a few hours of downtime for an ecommerce website’s search engine could cost millions of dollars in loss of sales). Furthermore, data scientists are on the bleeding edge—in order to discover new patterns and build impactful, data-driven innovations, they want to access and collect all the data they can get their hands on and use all the technologies that can help them get there. But setting up ways to collect new data, giving access to X logs, or installing new technological stacks on existing frameworks requires more work from the IT teams who’ve set up the actual data systems in the first place. The two visions, approaches, and expectations have trouble coexisting. Historical reasons: IT/engineering teams have existed in big companies for 20+ years in some cases. They are part of the old and proven establishment, following the mindset “if it isn’t broken, don’t touch it.” Data science teams have only existed for the past 5 years, and yet they are treated like royalty, whereas IT teams tend to be treated as a maintenance team or as a simple commodity. In reality, however, data scientists truly depend on IT teams to give them access to data, help them install new tech stacks, or implement their work in production. Without IT teams, most organisations would not function, and data science teams could not run their projects in production and therefore not prove the value that their work brings to the company. Consequently, both companies and data science teams are truly dependent on IT teams, but IT teams are usually not valued as such. The solution? Hybrid teams made of data scientists and engineers that are themselves responsible for running models in production. Prerequisite Knowledge:A basic understanding of how advanced analytic solutions (ie. data products and machine-learning-driven solutions) are actually built and the process required for them to be deployed What you'll learn:Understand why building and deploying advanced analytics solutions on an enterprise level requires collaboration of people and of technologies beyond data scientists Location: 328/329 Agenda: 11:15am to 11:55am - The barriers to production: A tech problem or a cultural one? Speaker: Pauline Brown is director of marketing at Dataiku, which has developed the most productive predictive services development platform for data professionals, Data Science Studio (DSS). Pauline is a firm believer that the data and predictive analytics ecosystem is entering a new era; one in which even nontechnical members of the data team can transform raw data into business-impacting solutions. After all, as a marketer at Dataiku, data-driven projects in DSS are part of her daily routine. Born and raised in Palo Alto, California, Pauline graduated from Columbia University before joining Paris’s IEP. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. For more information on the event, please visit: http://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg For deeper engagement with Apache Apex, download, view past meetup webinars, slides, and docs.  To reduce time to market, look at operable app-templates that you can quickly import and launch.  Examples: HDFS-Sync, Kafka-HDFS, HDFS-Line-Copy, S3-HDFS and HDFS-Kafka.

events.name: Case studies of business transformation through big data @ Strata+Hadoop WorldSG
events.description: This session is a part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: The opportunity to harness data to impact business is ripe, and as a result, every industry, every organization, and every department is going through a huge change, whether they realize it or not. Whether they are renovating their existing infrastructure for substantial cost savings or innovating their architecture to find new business opportunities, the impact is undeniable. John Kreisa reviews industry trends and shares use cases from across Asia and Europe of businesses that are successfully leveraging new platform technologies to transform their organization using data. What you'll learn:Understand what's driving big data adoption, the most common use cases for big data, the benefits organizations are receiving now, and real-world use cases currently in production. Location: 328/329 Agenda: 12:05pm to 12:45pm - Case studies of business transformation through big data Speaker: John Kreisa leads international marketing for Hortonworks, where he is responsible for all marketing activities across Europe and Asia. John has been with Hortonworks for more than four years and has been on the inside through massive growth in the big data market, including Apache Hadoop and related technologies. With more than 20 years of marketing experience across storage, analytics, and big data, John has extensive experience helping organizations understand the benefits of technologies. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. events.name: The fallacy of the subject-matter expert @ Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore
events.description: This session is a part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: In the world of data, the legend of the subject-matter expert has reached near-mythical proportions—a wondrous individual who would change the course of the company and, if the stories are to be believed, humanity itself, if only she had access to the data she needed. For decades, business intelligence companies have strived to make their products easier to use in the hope that they could finally reach this enterprise savior. But what if she doesn’t exist? Chris Neumann shares the lessons learned by the team at DataHero (acquired in January 2016 by Cloudability), which released the first BI product that empowered subject-matter experts to work directly with the data locked away in SaaS services like Salesforce, HubSpot, and Google Analytics. Chris discusses the team’s experiences bringing BI directly to subject-matter experts and shows that, contrary to popular belief, providing subject-matter experts with an easy-to-use UI and direct access to data is not always sufficient for a project to be successful. Using contrasting case studies, Chris presents a framework for determining whether a project’s target users are, indeed, subject-matter experts in the “mythical” sense. What you'll learn:Learn why, contrary to popular belief, providing subject-matter experts with an easy-to-use UI and direct access to data is not always sufficient for a project to be successful. Location: 328/329 Agenda: 1:45pm to 2:25pm - The fallacy of the subject-matter expert Speaker: Chris Neumann is big data veteran who has been at the forefront of data innovation for more than 10 years. He was the founder and CEO of DataHero (recently acquired by Cloudability), which brought to market the first self-service cloud BI platform. Previously, he was the first employee at Aster Data Systems (acquired by Teradata), where he helped create the big data space. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. events.name: BI and SQL analytics with Hadoop in the cloud @ Strata+Hadoop World - Singapore
events.description: This session is part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: Today, Apache Hadoop is deployed both on-premises and on the public cloud with the public cloud increasingly becoming more prevalent. The cloud provides some unique abilities, such as on-demand infrastructure, cluster elasticity, persisted globally available object storage, and pay-for-use pricing. This enables even more flexible and cost-efficient deployment options for BI and SQL analytic users of Impala but brings in some new challenges that need to be carefully considered to achieve optimal outcome. Alex Gutow and Henry Robinson explain how Apache Hadoop and Apache Impala (incubating) take advantage of the benefits of the cloud to provide the same great functionality, partner ecosystem, and flexibility of on-premises deployments combined with the flexibility and cost-efficiency cloud. Topics include: On-premises versus the cloud: What’s the same and what’s differentInstance types to consider for best performanceHow Impala can read/write on cloud-based object storage (S3)How to understand workloads in transient, hybrid, and permanent cloud clusters and what workloads are cost effective to run on the cloud versus on-premisesTuning and best practices for storage and instance choices that will help you effectively architect Impala clustersBI and SQL analytics with Hadoop in the cloudHow Impala performs in the cloud compared to alternativesRoadmap and what’s next Prerequisite Knowledge:A basic understanding of SQL and cloud principles What you'll learn:Understand the benefits and trade-offs of doing SQL analytics in the cloud Location: Summit 2 Agenda: 2:35pm to 3:15pm - BI and SQL analytics with Hadoop in the cloud Speakers: Alex Gutow is senior product marketing manager at Cloudera, focused on the analytic database platform solution and technologies. Prior to Cloudera, she managed technical marketing and PR for Basho Technologies and managed consumer and enterprise marketing for Truaxis, a MasterCard company. Alex holds a BS in marketing and BA in psychology from Carnegie Mellon University. Henry Robinson is a software engineer at Cloudera. For the past few years, he has worked on Apache Impala, an SQL query engine for data stored in Apache Hadoop, and leads the scalability effort to bring Impala to clusters of thousands of nodes. Henry’s main interest is in distributed systems. He is a PMC member for the Apache ZooKeeper, Apache Flume, and Apache Impala open source projects. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. events.name: Algorithmic art and data creativity @ Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore
events.description: This session is a part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: When it comes to data visualizations, we usually think of infographics. But besides data as storytelling, journalism, and dashboards, data has grown into a medium for expression for a large spectrum of creative output. Parametric design, algorithmic architecture, and rapid prototyping technologies have redefined the relationship between creator and artist tools. Contemporary artists are still struggling to find the language for a new contemporary output and practice in the post-Internet genre. The online world is bingeing, but it is also a rapidly changing. Artistic expression within the digital arts has brought forward critical examination of technology and its impact on society, such as surveillance and self-determination, and has often collaged quotations of all aspects of media and consumerism, questioning art market concepts like authorship and intellectual property rights, in mediums ranging from video, software, and websites to hardware, kinetic machines, and robotics. In some cases, the next generation of digital artists, responding to their own experiences of the online world, have affected what is being known as a staunchly Web 1.0 aesthetic. At the same time, parametric or generative art is being created from algorithms without direct human intervention. Heather Dewey-Hagborg and Joerg Blumtritt illustrate current developments with examples of recent bodies of work and discuss possible routes of art driven by data and algorithms. What you'll learn:Understand current developments of art driven by data and algorithms Location: 310/311 Agenda: 4:15pm to 4:55pm - Algorithmic art and data creativity Speakers: Joerg Blumtritt is the founder and CEO of Datarella, a computational social science startup delivering mobile analytics, self-tracking solutions, and data science consulting. After graduating from university with a thesis on machine learning, Joerg worked as a researcher in behavioral sciences, focused on nonverbal communication. His projects have been funded by an EU commission, the German federal government, and the Max Planck Society. He subsequently ran marketing and research teams for TV networks ProSiebenSat.1 and RTL II and magazine publisher Hubert Burda Media. As European operations officer at Tremor Media, Joerg was in charge of building the New York-based video advertising network’s European enterprises. More recently, he was managing director of MediaCom Germany. Joerg is the founder and chairman of the German Social Media Association (AG Social Media) and the coauthor of the Slow Media Manifesto. Joerg blogs about big data and the future of social research at Beautifuldata.net and about the Quantified Self at Datarella.com. Heather Dewey-Hagborg is a NYC-based transdisciplinary artist and educator who is interested in art as research and critical practice. She has shown work internationally at events and venues including the World Economic Forum, Ars Electronica in Linz, the Shenzhen Urbanism and Architecture Bienniale, Poland Mediations Bienniale, Article Biennial in Norway, the Science Gallery Dublin, Transmediale in Berlin, Fotomuseum Winterthur, Centre de Cultura Contemporània de Barcelona, ZKM Museum of Contemporary Art in Germany, Museum Boijmans, Van Abbemuseum, and MU Art Space in the Netherlands. She has exhibited nationally at PS1 Moma, the New Museum, Eyebeam, the New York Public Library, and the Utah Museum of Contemporary Art among many others. In addition to her individual work she has collaborated with the collective Future Archaeology, with video artist Adriana Varella and with artists Thomas Dexter, Aurelia Moser, Allison Burtch, and Adam Harvey. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. events.name: Organizing the data lake @ Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore
events.description: This session is a part of Strata + Hadoop World - Singapore. We are promoting this event on behalf of our community member. You must register with the event to book your seat. Strata + Hadoop World is where cutting-edge data science and new business fundamentals merge. It’s a deep-immersion experience where data scientists, analysts, and business executives dissect case studies, develop new skills, share emerging best practices, and build the future of big data. Abstract: Building a data lake involves more than installing and using Hadoop. The focus in the market has been on all the different technology components, ignoring the more important part: the data architecture that the code implements, which lies at the core of the system. Just like a data warehouse, a data lake has a data architecture. If you expect any longevity from the platform, the architecture should be designed rather than accidental. But what are the design principles that lead to good functional design and a workable data architecture? What are the assumptions that limit old approaches? How can one integrate with or migrate from the older environments? How does this affect an organization’s data management? Answering these questions is key to building long-term infrastructure. The goal in most organizations is to build multiuse data infrastructure that is not subject to past constraints. Mark Madsen discusses hidden design assumptions, reviews design principles to apply when building multiuse data infrastructure, and provides a reference architecture. This reference architecture has been used across many organizations to work toward a unified analytic infrastructure. Prerequisite Knowledge:A basic understanding of databases (relational and nonrelational), system architectures, and how data is used in an organization What you'll learn:Learn a reference architecture to help understand when to save immutable data, when to standardize it, and how to manage its delivery and use over time Location: Summit 2 Agenda: 5:05pm to 5:45pm - Organizing the data lake Speaker: Mark Madsen is a research analyst at Third Nature, where he advises companies on data strategy and technology planning. Mark has designed analysis, data collection, and data management infrastructure for companies worldwide. He focuses on two types of work: the business applications of data and guiding the construction of data infrastructure. As a result, Mark does as much information strategy and IT architecture work as he does performance management and analytics. ****You must register with the event to book your seat**** Register here: https://conferences.oreilly.com/strata/hadoop-big-data-sg/public/register We are promoting selected sessions of this event as they align with our group interests. events.name: BigDataSG at Strata/Hadoop Singapore
events.description: How are we going to top the stellar lineup we had at last year's BigDataSG meetup at Strata?   It's simple: we invite back a couple of the awesome speakers we had last year to talk about new topics--and add one more big name headliner to the roster! So brace yourself, here are the speakers:   Doug Cutting.  Yes--that Doug Cutting.  The father of Hadoop and the Chief Architect at Cloudera. Ted Dunning.  Chief Application Architect at MapR, PMC member for Apache Mahout, Zookeeper and Drill and possibly the smartest guy on earth--and a very entertaining speaker. MC Srivas. Chief Data Architect at Uber.  MC Srivas was previously the co-founder and CTO of MapR and is now leading the charge to efficiently use all of Uber's data. Truly some big data rock stars.  You won't want to miss this. The event is free and open to the public.  Please register to attend. Hope to see you there!
events.location: Suntec Convention Center, Suntec Convention Center, Singapore

events.name: Friends of PyData SG: Stream Processing & TensorFlow 101 at Google APAC
events.description: Register at https://events.withgoogle.com/stream-processing-and-tensorflow-101/. RSVP on Meetup page is not sufficient for attending the event. Good things come in pairs! Not only do we have PyData SG @ Strata + Hadoop World 2016, Google has an event about Apache Beam and TensorFlow! Together with Google, we invite you to join our Google friends to learn more about Apache Beam, Data Stream processing and TensorFlow. It is an amazing opportunity to meet with the Googlers building your favourite products. Light F&B will be provided at the event.
events.location: Google Asia Pacific, Mapletree Business City, 70 Pasir Panjang Rd, Singapore 117371

events.name: Visualization, mapping and event processing for data scientists
events.description: Dr. Michael O'Connell, Chief Analytics Officer of TIBCO, is in town. During an interactive session, Michael will touch on several interesting use cases where data scientists are using a combination of analytics, visualization, mapping and event processing for rapidly driving business value. Examples from a number of industries and functions will be covered including: ·  Advanced mapping analysis such as adding interactive contour lines to maps on the fly ·  Predictive analytics applications including, probability plotting, clustering and regression ·  Reliability analysis and monitoring ·  Visualization and dashboards for interactive business applications Light refreshments will be provided.  About the speaker:  Michael O'Connell is Chief Analytics Officer at TIBCO Software, helping clients with analytics software applications that drive extreme business value. Michael's passion involves identifying insights with visual and predictive analytics, and turning these insights into actions across business operations—with real-time, event processing. He has worked extensively in many industries, driving TIBCO product direction to address business problems in Financial Services, Energy, Life Sciences, Consumer Goods & Retail, and Telco, Media & Networks. Michael has written more than 50 scientific papers and several software packages on statistical methods. His current book, "A Picture is Worth a Thousand Tables," is published by Springer. Michael did his Ph.D. work in Statistics at North Carolina State University and is Adjunct Professor of Statistics in the department.
events.location: The Workshop, The Working Capitol, 1 Keong Saik Road, Singapore

events.name: End of Year Kx Meetup
events.description: Hi All, We are hosting our end of year Kx Community Singapore Meetup event on Thursday, 8th of December. We would like to take this opportunity to thank everyone in the Singapore Kx community who has attended and participated in the Kx meetups throughout the year. Your interest is greatly appreciated and has significantly contributed to what is a growing Kx community in Singapore and we look forward to working with you all once again in the coming year. Please join us for a night of networking and talks by 2 speakers involved in high performance Big Data Analytics. Complimentary drinks and food will be served. Guest Speakers: Sam Stanton-Cook, Kx Sam is a pre-sales consultant and developer for Kx and will be providing a Christmas themed demo using our brand new Analyst for Kx for real-time data transformation, exploration and discovery of massive datasets using an intuitive point-and-click interface. Anton Dovzhenko, Senior Software Engineer at Standard Chartered Bank Anton will be discussing why his team has chosen Kdb+ in favour of ‘One Tick’ and will be walking through the migration findings. Date: Thursday, December 8th, 2016 Venue: Harry’s bar, Level 2 (upstairs), Boat Quay Time: 6:30pm – 9:00pm
events.location: Harry's Bar @ Boat Quay (Proceed to Top Floor), 28 Boat Quay,, Singapore

events.name: Humla Workshop - Metasploit Framework
events.description:
We are pleased to inform Humla Hands-On workshop on Metasploit Framework by Sayed Hamzah Alhabshe  Please note, this is an invite only but FREE  hands-on workshop, we can accommodate only few selected participants. If you get selected, you will receive email from humla champion a week before the event. *** We are looking for more speakers to contribute to this series. Please get in touch if you are interested.   Selection Criteria: Selection (15-20 persons only) will be based on the following two criteria: 1. Contribution to the community. Speakers, humla, bachav champions, core team, volunteers  and venue hosts will get priority to the workshop.  2. Passion towards Information security + the attendance in previous meet ups.   If you are new to the community, selection will be based on the answers to the survey questions asked during the registration process. Please answer these questions carefully.  Agenda:  We will cover the following topics: 1) Introduction of Metasploit (15 min) - Quick overview of Metasploit (Setup)- Quick navigation 2) Metasploit Uses (45 min) - Quick overview of metasploit module categories and types- Saving credentials using metasploit (requires switching on the postgresql) - Small exercise: hack a server that is metasploitable (all network recon, and exploit stuff to be done within metasploit) 3) Writing a metasploit module  (pre-requisite: just need to know vanilla buffer overflow, 45 min) - Components of a metasploit module - Small exercise 2: Create a custom metasploit module based on a customised server that has a linux buffer overflow application. 


Pre-requisites: None. 


Who should attend ? :  Anyone who is interested in pentesting, vulnerability assessment and security in general.  


What should I bring with me? : Hardware: Laptop which can run two VMs simultaneously with at least 4 GB RAM and minimum 30 GB hard disk free space. Software:   1. VMware Player Installed with Kali Linux 2. Metasploitable VM, Windows XP VM. 3. More instructions will be sent via email.  


Null humla champion: Sayed Hamzah Hamzah has a vast amount of experience, providing consultancy and support work with various organisations in both the public and private sector. Currently working in Centurion Information Security, he is able to deliver clients with substantial results with his unique skillset he has acquired over the years of work experience. His skillset is further complimented with his acquisition of OSCP and CREST Registered Tester (CRT) certifications. In addition, Hamzah has been actively involved in the establishment of the Offensive Cyber Security Club in Nanyang Technological University, providing training for club members who have a keen interest in vulnerability assessment and penetration testing as a career in the future. He has also been actively participating in cyber security competitions such as the Cyber Defenders Discovery Camp by DSTA and the X-CTF competition hosted by NUS Greyhats 



Please reach out to humla champion, if you have any questions regarding the event.
events.group_name: Null Singapore - The Open Security Community

events.name: CodingGirls Tech Talk - The Future of Chatbots
events.description:
Are Chatbots just hype or the next big thing?
What does the future hold for the chatbot, a conversation-based computer program that interacts with people via a chat interface?
Join us for an exciting evening where we discuss the technicalities and potential uses of Chatbots.

events.name: CODING GIRLS TECH TALK: The Future of Chatbots
events.description:
Register for your slot here: http://codinggirlstechtalkchatbots.peatix.com/ Are Chatbots just hype or the next big thing? Earlier this year, Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella was quoted as saying that Chatbots will “fundamentally revolutionize how computing is experienced by everyone”. In fact, early adopting big brands such as KLM, Burberry, Pizza hut and Sephora have begun experimenting with chatbots to reach over 1 billion active users on Facebook Messenger ever since bots were introduced to the messaging app in April 2016. What does the future hold for the chatbot, a conversation-based computer program that interacts with people via a chat interface? Join us for an exciting evening where we discuss the technicalities and potential uses of Chatbots. SPEAKERS:   



Abhilash Murty Creator of comical local bus service chatbot, Bus Uncle, Abhilash Murty is currently a software engineer with TradeGecko. He will be sharing his experience building the part snarky, part witty, Singlish spewing, much beloved popular Bus Uncle and elaborating on the usage of chatbots in general.Read more about Abhilash Bus Uncle here: http://www.todayonline.com/singapore/meet-man-behind-bus-uncle.   


Alyssa Ong Featured in VentureBeat as one of the 100 people to watch in the chatbot space, Alyssa has been working with bots since the early days of Microsoft Bot Framework's release. Alyssa, also a World Finalist in the Microsoft Imagine Cup, has published multiple bots publicly to date. As a former Microsoft student partner, Alyssa had also conducted talks and technical workshops to hundreds of students. An all-round bot nerd, she is an active member of the Chatbots News community and loves discussing bots with others.Alyssa will share how you can get on the chatbot movement with Microsoft Bot Framework. She will also present bot demos and real life use cases.  


Kester PohKester Poh is the Co-Founder of AiChat, a chatbot-as-a-service platform that empowers companies to easily deliver content, automate replies, and engage customers via Facebook Messenger.Prior starting AiChat, Kester worked with some of the largest digital agencies in the WPP network on multiple award-winning digital campaigns for the Fortune 500 clients. He was recently featured on VentureBeat “100 people to watch in the chatbot space”. One of his chatbots, AskVoila, a digital personal shopping assistant was featured on e27 and Yahoo News “5 Singaporean chatbots you will actually use”. Kester will speak on the opportunities and business use cases of chatbots, and how chatbots can help businesses. In addition, he will touch on topics such as how to run a business with chatbot products

events.name: December Meetup
events.description:
Hi folks!  Join us for our inaugural API Craft Singapore meetup on the 8th of December at 7pm. See you all soon! 


Programme  7.00pm: Doors open - mingle over pizzas and drinks 7.20pm: Start of session, opening address by hosts 7.30pm: Start of scheduled talks 9:00pm:  Community announcements / End of event 


Scheduled Talks (30 mins each) - Anti-Patterns in Web API Design by Aivan - Design and Document your REST APIs with Swagger by Shi Ling - GraphQL in an Age of REST by Yos Interested in giving a talk? You could share about your API development workflow, API design best practices, new technologies, and/or projects you're currently working on.  Information for Attendees Remember to bring a photo ID to get through building security! The meetup will be hosted at PayPal Singapore, Suntec Tower 5, Level 9 at 5 Temasek Boulevard.  If you're traveling by MRT, the closest MRT stations are CC4 Promenade and CC3 Esplanade. If you're traveling by bus, the closest bus stop is 02159 Opp Suntec Convention Centre. Job Opportunities Have a job position you'd like to announce? Contact us from the 'Contact' button on the sidebar, and we'll post it here. Sponsor(s)  Venue sponsor: PayPal Food and drink sponsor: PayPal  Thank you to all our sponsors!
events.location: PayPal Singapore, Suntec Tower 5, 5 Temasek Boulevard #09-01 , Singapore
